perturbation.original_text: WPD hereby agrees to hold harmless and indemnify CNS, its officers, affiliates, employees, and agents (the “CNS Indemnitees”) from and against any and all third party claims, demands, causes of actions, costs of suit and reasonable and documented attorney’s fees (collectively “Claims”) caused by, arising out of, or resulting from WPD’s, its employees, agents’, affiliates’, licensees’, sublicensees’ or subcontractors’ (i) negligence or willful misconduct; (ii) breach of any warranty or representations set forth herein; (iii) breach or alleged breach of third party intellectual property rights; and (iv) use or sale of Development Products.
perturbation.changed_text: WPD agrees to endeavor to indemnify CNS, its officers, affiliates, employees, and agents (the “CNS Indemnitees”) from third party claims, demands, causes of actions, costs of suit and attorney’s fees (collectively “Claims”) possibly caused by, arguably arising out of, or speculatively resulting from WPD’s, its employees, agents’, affiliates’, licensees’, sublicensees’ or subcontractors’ (i) negligence or willful misconduct; (ii) breach of any warranty or representations set forth herein; (iii) breach or alleged breach of third party intellectual property rights; and (iv) use or sale of Development Products.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing "hereby agrees to hold harmless and indemnify" with "agrees to endeavor to indemnify" weakens the obligation to indemnify. Changing "caused by, arising out of, or resulting from" to "possibly caused by, arguably arising out of, or speculatively resulting from" introduces uncertainty about the causal link required for indemnification. Limiting "reasonable and documented attorney's fees" to just "attorney's fees" potentially introduces ambiguity regarding the scope and recoverability of these expenses. This violates the principle of clear and unambiguous contract terms, potentially making the indemnification clause unenforceable under Texas law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of Contract under Texas Law - Ambiguous Contract Terms

perturbation.original_text: 7.2.2 WPD, and its affiliates, shall at all times keep books, records and accounts which, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of their assets and maintain a system of internal accounting controls sufficient to provide reasonable assurances that transactions are properly authorized and recorded;
perturbation.changed_text: 7.2.2 WPD, and its affiliates, will attempt to keep books, records and accounts which, in their opinion, generally reflect the transactions and dispositions of their assets and maintain a system of internal accounting controls they deem sufficient.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "shall at all times keep books, records and accounts which, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect" to "will attempt to keep books, records and accounts which, in their opinion, generally reflect" introduces subjectivity and weakens the requirement for accurate record-keeping. Replacing "sufficient to provide reasonable assurances" with "they deem sufficient" further weakens the obligation and introduces a subjective standard. This contradicts the FCPA's requirements for maintaining accurate and transparent financial records and internal controls.
perturbation.contradicted_law: U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) - Accounting Provisions

perturbation.original_text: 5.4 Data Privacy and Security Laws. WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) will at all times during the Term be in material compliance with all applicable data privacy and security laws and regulations, and WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) have taken or will take commercially reasonable actions to comply with the European Union General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) (EU 2016/679) and all other applicable laws and regulations with respect to Personal Data (defined below) that have been announced as of the date hereof as becoming effective within 12 months after the date hereof, and for which any non-compliance with same would be reasonably likely to create a material liability (collectively, the “Privacy Laws”). To WPD’s knowledge, WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) have been and currently are in material compliance with the GDPR. To ensure material compliance with the Privacy Laws, WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) have taken, and currently take, commercially reasonable steps reasonably designed to ensure compliance in all material respects with Privacy Laws relating to data privacy and security and the collection, storage, use, disclosure, handling, and analysis of Personal Data that WPD has collected, and collects, or is in WPD’s possession or will be in WPD’s possession during the Term. “Personal Data” means "personal data" as defined by GDPR.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.4 Data Privacy and Security Laws. WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) will endeavor to be in compliance with what they perceive to be the core tenets of applicable data privacy and security laws and regulations during the Term, and WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) may attempt to take what they consider to be appropriate actions to comply with the European Union General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”) (EU 2016/679) and all other applicable laws and regulations with respect to Personal Data (defined below) that have been announced as of the date hereof as becoming effective within 12 months after the date hereof, and for which any non-compliance with same could potentially create a liability (collectively, the “Privacy Laws”). WPD believes that it and its subsidiaries (if any) have been and currently are generally in compliance with the GDPR. To ostensibly ensure compliance with the Privacy Laws, WPD and its subsidiaries (if any) have taken, and currently take, some steps intended to suggest compliance with Privacy Laws relating to data privacy and security and the collection, storage, use, disclosure, handling, and analysis of Personal Data that WPD has collected, and collects, or is in WPD’s possession or will be in WPD’s possession during the Term. “Personal Data” means "personal data" as defined by GDPR.
perturbation.explanation: Modifying "will at all times during the Term be in material compliance" to "will endeavor to be in compliance with what they perceive to be the core tenets" weakens the compliance obligation and introduces subjectivity. Changing "commercially reasonable actions to comply" to "may attempt to take what they consider to be appropriate actions to comply" makes compliance discretionary. Replacing "reasonably likely to create a material liability" with "could potentially create a liability" lowers the threshold for triggering compliance efforts. Replacing "To ensure material compliance" with "To ostensibly ensure compliance" questions the intent and Replacing "commercially reasonable steps reasonably designed to ensure compliance" with "some steps intended to suggest compliance", suggesting the efforts are for show rather than actual compliance. This change makes it easier for WPD to argue they are compliant even if their actions do not fully meet GDPR standards. The vague language provides an opportunity for WPD to avoid liability, even in cases where clear breaches of GDPR have occurred.
perturbation.contradicted_law: European Union General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
